2. He said to him, “Far be it! You shall not die! Behold, my father does not do anything great or small without revealing it to me. Why then should my father conceal this matter from me? It is not so.”

3. Dovid swore to him again, and said, “Your father certainly knows that I have found favor in your eyes, and said [to himself], ‘Yonoson should not know of this, lest he be saddened.’ However, as Adonoy lives, and by your life, there is but a step between me and death.”
4. Yonoson said to Dovid, “Whatever your soul says I will do for you.”
5. Dovid said to Yonoson, “Behold, tomorrow is the New Moon, and I usually sit with the king to eat. Let me leave and I will hide in the field until the third evening.
6. If your father notices my absence, then say, ‘Dovid asked me to let him hurry off to Beis Lechem, his city, for there is an annual feast-offering there for the entire family.’
7. If he says thus, ‘Good,’ then it is well for your servant. But if he gets very angry, you should know that he has decided upon evil.
8. Be kind to your servant, for into a covenant of Adonoy you have brought your servant with you; if I am guilty of any sin, kill me yourself, why bring me to your father?”
9. Yonoson said, “Far be it from you! If I were to know that my father has decided upon evil against you, would I not tell it to you?”
10. Dovid then said to Yonoson, “Who will tell me if your father answers you harshly?”
11. Yonoson said to Dovid, “Come, let us go out to the field,” and the two of them went out to the field.

12. Yonoson said to Dovid, “[I swear by] Adonoy the God of Yisroel that I will sound out my father at this time on the third day from now, and behold, if it is good for Dovid, will I then not send for you and let you know?

13. So may Adonoy do to Yonoson and much more, if it pleases my father to harm you, I will let you know, and I will send you away that you may go safely; and may Adonoy be with you as He was with my father.
14. I will not [ask of you] if I will still be alive that you not do for me Adonoy’s kindness, so that I will not die?
15. And that you do not cut off your kindness from my descendants forever; not even when Adonoy cuts off each of Dovid’s enemies from the face of the earth.”
16. Yonoson made a covenant regarding Dovid’s household, “May Adonoy exact punishment from Dovid’s enemies.”
17. Yonoson again had Dovid take an oath, because of his love for him; for he loved him as he loved himself.
18. Yonoson said to him, “Tomorrow is the New Moon, and you will be missed because your seat will be empty.
19. For three days you are to remain far down. Then come to the place where you hid on the day of the incident, and stay near the marker stone.
20. I will shoot three arrows in that direction as if I were shooting at a target.

21. Behold, I will then send the lad [saying], ‘Go find the arrows.’ If I repeatedly say to the lad, ‘Behold, the arrows are on this side of you,’ then take [the arrows] and come, for all is well with you and there is no concern, as Adonoy lives.
22. But if I say thus to the young man, ‘Behold, the arrows are on the far side of you,’ then go, for Adonoy has sent you away.
23. But as for the matter of which we have spoken, I and you, behold, Adonoy is [witness] between me and you forever.”
24. Dovid hid in the field; it was the New Moon and the king sat down to eat.
25. The king sat on his seat as at other times, on the seat against the wall. Yonoson rose and Avneir sat at Shaul’s side, and Dovid’s place was empty.
26. Shaul said nothing on that day, for he said [to himself], “something happened, he must be impure, for he is not ritually pure.”
27. It was the day after the New Moon, the second [day], and Dovid’s place was empty. Shaul said to Yonoson, his son, “Why has the son of Yishay not come to the meal neither yesterday nor today?”
28. Yonoson answered Shaul, “Dovid repeatedly asked me for permission [to go] to Beis Lechem.

29. He said, ‘Please let me go, for we have a family feast-offering in the city, and he, my brother, summoned me. So now, if I have found favor in your eyes, please let me hurry off and see my brothers.’ Therefore he did not come to the king’s table.”

30. Shaul’s anger raged against Yonoson, and he said to him, “[You] son of a straying woman deserving of punishment! Do I not know that you choose Yishay’s son, to your own disgrace and to the disgrace of your mother’s unchastity?
31. For as long as Yishay’s son is alive on the earth, you and your kingdom will not be established. Now send and bring him to me, for he deserves to die!”
32. Yonoson answered his father Shaul, and said to him, “Why should he die? What has he done?”
33. Shaul raised the spear at him to strike him; thus Yonoson realized that his father had decided to kill Dovid.
34. Yonoson rose from the table in a rage; he did not partake—on the second day of the month—of food, for he was saddened over Dovid, because his father had humiliated him.
35. The following morning Yonoson went out to the field for the meeting with Dovid, and a young boy accompanied him.
36 He said to his lad, “Run, please find the arrows that I shoot.” The lad ran, and he shot the arrow beyond him.
37. The lad came to the place of the arrow that Yonoson had shot, and Yonoson called out after the lad and said, “Is not the arrow beyond you?”
38. Yonoson then called out after the lad, “Quickly, hurry, do not delay!” Yonoson’s lad gathered the arrows and came to his master.
39. The lad knew nothing, only Yonoson and Dovid knew the matter.
40. Yonoson gave his things to his lad and said to him, “Go, bring them to the city.”

41. The lad went and Dovid rose from near the southern side [of the stone], and he fell on his face to the ground and prostrated himself three times. Each man kissed the other and they cried with one another, until Dovid exceeded.

42. Yonoson said to Dovid, “Go to peace. For the two of us have sworn in the Name of Adonoy, saying, ‘Adonoy will be [a witness] between me and you, and between my offspring and your offspring, forever!’”
1. He [Dovid] rose and left, and Yonoson returned to the city.
2. Dovid came to Noveh, to Achimelech the kohein. Achimelech came trembling toward Dovid, and said to him, “Why are you alone, with no one accompanying you?”

3. Dovid said to Achimelech the kohein, “The king ordered me on a mission, and told me, ‘Let no man know anything of the matter about which I am sending you and have commanded you.’ And as for the youths, I have sent them ahead to a certain secret place.
4. And now, what do you have available? Five loaves of bread? Give them, or whatever there is, into my hand.”
5. The kohein answered Dovid, saying, “I have no ordinary bread available, there is only sacred bread; provided the youths have kept themselves at least from women.”

6. Dovid answered the kohein, saying to him, “Women have been kept from us yesterday and the day before, when I left; the garments of the youths were pure, even though it is an ordinary mission, even more so today it will remain sacred in the vessel.”
7. The kohein gave him sacred [bread], for there was no [other] bread there, except for the showbread that was removed from before Adonoy, in order to put hot bread on the day it was taken off.
8. One of Shaul’s servants was there on that day, who remained before Adonoy; his name was Do’eg the Edomite, chief of Shaul’s shepherds.
9. Dovid then said to Achimelech, “Perhaps you have in your possession a spear or a sword, for my sword and my weapons I did not take with me, because the king’s mission was urgent.”

10. The kohein said, “The sword of Golyos the Philistine, whom you slew in the Eiloh Valley, behold it is here, wrapped up in a cloth behind the eiphod; if you will take it, take it, for there is no other but that one.” Dovid said, “There is none like it; give it to me.”
11. Dovid rose and fled from Shaul on that day, and he came to Achish, king of Gas.

12. The servants of Achish said to him, “Is this not Dovid, the king of the land? Is it not of him that they sing and play with musical instruments, saying, ‘Shaul has slain his thousands, and Dovid his tens of thousands?’”
13. Dovid took this matter to heart and was very afraid of Achish, king of Gas.
14. He changed his behavior in front of them and feigned madness while he was with them; he scribbled on the doors of the gate and let his saliva drip on his beard.
15. Achish said to his servants, “Behold, you see the man is mad. Why have you brought him to me?
16. Do I lack madmen that you brought this one to display his madness in front of me? Should such [a person] come into my house?”
1. Dovid went from there and escaped to the cave of Adullom. His brothers and all his father’s house heard, and they went down to him there.
2. They gathered to him—every man in distress, every man in debt, and every man with an embittered spirit—and he became their leader; there were with him about four hundred men.
3. Dovid went from there to the Mitzpeh of Moav, and he said to the king of Moav, “Please let my father and mother come out [and stay] with you until I know what God will do for me.”
4. He brought them before the king of Moav and they remained with him all the time that Dovid was in the fortress.
5. Gad the prophet said to Dovid, “Do not stay in the fortress; go and return to the land of Yehudah. Dovid went and arrived at the forest of Chares.

6. Shaul heard that they had been discovered—Dovid and the men who were with him. Shaul was staying in Givah beneath the tamarisk tree in Romoh; his spear in his hand, and all his servants standing about him.

7. Shaul said to his servants who were standing about him, “Listen now you Binyominites. Will Yishay’s son give you all fields and vineyards? Will he make you all officers of thousands and officers of hundreds?

8. That all of you have conspired against me and no one revealed to me that my son made a pact with Yishay’s son, and that none among you worried about me or let me know that my son has set my servant against me, to ambush me this day.”
9. Then Doeg the Edomite answered—who was in charge of Shaul’s servants—and said, “I saw Yishay’s son coming to Noveh, to Achimelech son of Achituv.
10. He inquired of Adonoy for him and gave him provisions, and the sword of Golyos the Philistine he [also] gave him.”
11. The king sent to call Achimelech son of Achituv the kohein, and all his father’s house, the kohanim that were in Nov; and they all came to the king.
12. Shaul said, “Listen now, son of Achituv!” And he said, “Here I am, my master.”
13. Shaul said to him, “Why did you conspire against me, you and Yishay’s son, by giving him bread and a sword, and inquiring of God for him, so that he could attack and ambush me this day?”
14. Achimelech answered the king, and said, “Who of all your servants is as trustworthy as Dovid, the king’s son-in-law, who bows to your bidding, and is honored in your household?

15. Did I begin today to inquire of God for him? Far be it from me! Let the king not accuse his servant or my father’s entire household of anything, for your servant knew nothing of this entire matter, either small or great.”
16. The king said, “You surely shall die, Achimelech, you and all your father’s house.”

17. The king then said to the runners who stood near him, “Surround and put to death the kohanim of Adonoy, because their hand is also with Dovid, for they knew that he was fleeing but did not reveal it to me.” But the servants of the king did not want to stretch forth their hand to slay the kohanim of Adonoy.
18. The king said to Do’eg, “You turn and slay the kohanim!” Do’eg the Edomite turned and he killed the kohanim; on that day he killed eighty-five men, who wore a linen eiphod.
19. And Nov, the city of kohanim, he killed by the sword; man and woman; child and suckling; ox, donkey and sheep, by the sword.
20. One son escaped; of Achimelech son of Achituv, his name was Evyosor, and he fled to Dovid.
21. Evyosor told Dovid that Shaul had killed the kohanim of Adonoy.
22. Dovid said to Evyosor, “I knew on that day when Do’eg the Edomite was there, that he would surely inform Shaul. I am responsible for every life of your father’s house.
23. Stay with me, fear not; for the man who seeks my life seeks your life. But with me, you are safe.”
1. They told Dovid, saying, “Behold, the Philistines are waging war against Ke’iloh and they are plundering the granaries.”
2. Dovid then inquired of Adonoy, saying, “Shall I go and attack these Philistines?” Adonoy said to Dovid, “Go, attack the Philistines and save Ke’iloh.”
3. Dovid’s men said to him, “Behold, here in Yehudah we are afraid; how much more so if we go to Ke’iloh, to the Philistine batallions.”
4. Dovid inquired further of Adonoy, and Adonoy answered him and said, “Rise, go down to Ke’iloh, for I will deliver the Philistines into your hand.”
5. Dovid and his men went to Ke’iloh and fought the Philistines; he led away their livestock and struck them a great blow. Thus Dovid saved the residents of Ke’iloh.
6. When Evyosor son of Achimelech fled to Dovid to Ke’iloh, he brought down the eiphod with him.
7. It was told to Shaul that Dovid had come Ke’iloh, and Shaul said, “God has given him into my hand, for he has been shut in by entering a city that has doors and a bolt.”
8. Shaul summoned all the people for war, to go down to Ke’iloh to besiege Dovid and his men.
9. Dovid knew that Shaul was planning evil against him, so he said to Evyosor the kohein, “Bring over the eiphod.”
10. Dovid said, “Adonoy, God of Yisroel, Your servant has heard that Shaul seeks to come to Ke’iloh to destroy the city because of me.

11. Will Ke’iloh’s residents hand me over into his hand? Will Shaul come down here, as Your servant has heard? O Adonoy God of Yisroel, please tell Your servant.” And Adonoy said, “He will come down.”
12. Dovid said, “Will Ke’iloh’s residents hand me and my men over into Shaul’s hand?” And Adonoy said, “They will hand [you] over.”
13. Dovid and his men rose—about six hundred men—and departed from Ke’iloh and went wherever they could go. Shaul was told that Dovid had escaped from Ke’iloh, and he refrained from going out.
14. Dovid dwelled in the wilderness, in strongholds, and he stayed in the mountain, in the wilderness of Ziph. Shaul searched for him all the days, but God did not deliver him into his hand.
15. Dovid saw that Shaul had gone out to seek his life, and Dovid was in the wilderness of Ziph, in Chorshoh.
16. Yonoson son of Shaul rose and went to Dovid to Chorshoh, and he strengthened his hand through [the word of] God.
17. He said to him, “Fear not, for the hand of my father Shaul will not find you; you will be king over Yisroel, and I will be second to you, even my father Shaul knows it.”
18. The two of them made a pact before Adonoy; Dovid stayed in Chorshoh, and Yonoson went to his home.
19. The Ziphites went up to Shaul, to Givah, saying, “Dovid is hiding among us in the strongholds of Chorshoh, in Givas Hachachiloh, south of Yeshimon.
20. So now, whenever the king desires to go down, go down, and it is ours to hand him over into the king’s hand.”
21. Shaul said, “May you be blessed by Adonoy, for taking pity upon me.
22. Please go and prepare further, and know and observe his location, where he will be, [and] who has seen him there, for [someone] told me that he is very cunning.

23. Observe and know all the hiding places where he hides, and return to me well prepared, then I will go with you. And it will be that if he is in the land, I will search for him among all the thousands of Yehudah.”
24. They rose and went to Ziph ahead of Shaul; but Dovid and his men were in the wilderness of Ma’on in the Arovoh, south of Yeshimon.
25. Shaul and his men went to search, but Dovid was told, so he went down towards the cliff and stayed in the wilderness of Ma’on. Shaul heard and pursued Dovid in the wilderness of Ma’on.

26. Shaul went from one side of the mountain while Dovid and his men went from the other side of the mountain; Dovid hurried to get away from Shaul, but Shaul and his men were surrounding Dovid and his men, to seize them.
27. A messenger came to Shaul, saying, “Hurry and come, for the Philistines have spread out over the land!”
28. So Shaul returned from pursuing Dovid, and he went toward the Philistines; therefore they named that place, “the Rock of Divisions.”
1. Dovid went up from there and stayed in the strongholds of Ein Gedi.
2. When Shaul returned from [pursuing] the Philistines, they told him, saying, “Behold, Dovid is in the wilderness of Ein Gedi.”
3. Shaul took three thousand chosen men from all of Yisroel, and he went to search for Dovid and his men, across the rocky land of the wild goats.
4. He came to the sheepfolds along the way, and there was a cave, which Shaul entered to relieve himself. Dovid and his men were sitting at the far end of the cave.

5. Dovid’s men said to him, “Behold, this is the day of which Adonoy said to you, ‘Behold, I am delivering your enemy into your hand, and you will do to him as you please.’” Dovid rose and cut off a corner of Shaul’s robe—stealthily.
6. Afterwards, however, Dovid’s heart pounded within him for having cut off the corner of Shaul’s [robe].
7. He said to his men, “Adonoy forbid that I should do this thing to my master, the anointed of Adonoy, to send forth my hand against him, for he is the anointed of Adonoy.”
8. Dovid pacified his men with words, and did not allow them to attack Shaul; Shaul rose from the cave and went on the way.

9. After that, Dovid rose and went out of the cave, and he called after Shaul, saying, “My master, the king.” Shaul looked behind him, and Dovid bowed with his face to the ground, and prostrated himself.
10. Dovid said to Shaul, “Why do you listen to the words of someone who says, ‘Behold, Dovid seeks to harm you’?

11. Behold, this day your eyes have seen how Adonoy has given you today into my hand, in the cave; someone said to kill you, but I had mercy on you, and I said, ‘I shall not send forth my hand against my master, for he is the anointed of Adonoy.’

12. My father, indeed, see the corner of your robe that is in my hand; by my cutting off the corner of your robe but not killing you, you should know and see that there is neither evil nor rebellion in my hand, and that I have not sinned against you, yet you hunt my soul to take it.
13. May Adonoy judge between me and you, and may Adonoy avenge me from you; but my hand will not act against you.
14. As the ancient proverb says, ‘From the wicked comes wickedness,’ but my hand will not act against you.
15. After whom has the king of Yisroel gone out? Whom are you pursuing? After a dead dog? After a single flea?
16. May Adonoy be judge, and let Him judge between me and you; let Him see and plead my cause, and exact my justice from your hand.”
17. When Dovid finished speaking these words to Shaul, Shaul said, “Is that your voice, my son Dovid?” Then Shaul raised his voice and wept.
18. He said to Dovid, “You are more righteous than I, for you have repaid me with goodness while I have repaid you with wickedness.
19. You have related today that you have done with me—the good, for Adonoy handed me over into your hand, yet you did not kill me.
20. If a man finds his enemy does he then send him off on a good way? May Adonoy repay you well for what you have done for me this day.
21. Now, behold, I know that you will surely reign, and it will be established in your hand—the kingship over Yisroel.
22. Now, swear to me by Adonoy that you will not cut off my descendants after me, and that you will not destroy my name from my father’s house.”
23. Dovid swore to Shaul. Shaul went to his house and Dovid and his men went up to the stronghold.
1. Shmuel died, and all of Yisroel gathered and mourned him, and they buried him at his home in Romoh. Dovid rose and went down to the wilderness of Poron.
2. There was a man in Ma’on whose business was in Carmel. The man was very wealthy; he had three thousand sheep and a thousand goats. It was the time when he was shearing his sheep in Carmel.
3. The man’s name was Novol and his wife’s name was Avigayil; the woman was intelligent and beautiful, but the man was hard and of evil deeds. He was a Calebite.
4. While Dovid was in the wilderness he heard that Novol was shearing his sheep.
5. Dovid sent ten youths, and Dovid said to the youths, “Go up to Carmel and come to Novol, and greet him in peace in my name.
6. And say, ‘May it always be so. Peace unto you, peace unto your household, and peace unto all that is yours.
7. Now, I have heard that they are shearing for you. Now, your shepherds were with us; we did not shame them and not a thing of theirs was missing all the time they were in Carmel.
8. Ask your youths and they will tell you; may the youths find favor in your eyes, for we have come on a festive day. Please give whatever you can spare to your servants and to your son, Dovid.’”
9. Dovid’s youths came and spoke to Novol in accordance with all these words, in Dovid’s name, and then they rested.
10. Novol replied to Dovid’s servants, and said, “Who is Dovid and who is the son of Yishay? Nowadays many are the servants who break away from their master.
11. Should I take from my bread and my water and my meat, that I have slaughtered for my shearers, and give them to men from where I do not know?”
12. Dovid’s youths turned back to their way; they returned and came, and told him all these things.

13. Dovid said to his men, “Each man gird his sword.” Each man girded his sword, and Dovid, too, girded his sword; and after Dovid went up about four hundred men, and two hundred others stayed with the equipment.
14. And to Avigayil, Novol’s wife, one youth from among the youths told, saying, “Behold, Dovid sent messengers from the wilderness to greet our master, but he chased them away.
15. And these men were very good to us; we were not shamed, nor did we miss anything all the time that we went with them, when we were in the field.
16. They protected us, both by night and by day, all the time we were with them tending the sheep.
17. Now know and see what you will do, for evil has been decided against our master and upon his entire household; he is too wicked a person to speak to.”

18. So Avigayil hurried and took two hundred breads, two flasks of wine, five prepared sheep, five seah of toasted grain, a hundred clusters of raisins, and two hundred cakes of pressed figs, and she put them on the donkeys.
19. She said to her youths, “Go on ahead of me; I am coming right behind you.” But to Novol her husband she said nothing.
20. And it happened, as she was riding on the donkey, going down the hidden part of the mountain, and behold, Dovid and his men were going down toward her, and she met them.
21. Dovid said [to himself], “It was for naught that I guarded all that this one has in the wilderness and that nothing of his was missing; yet he has repaid my kindness with evil.
22. Such shall God do to Dovid’s enemies and such shall He do further, if I leave over of all that belongs to him until daybreak—even one dog.”
23. When Avigayil saw Dovid, she hurried and dismounted from the donkey; she fell on her face before Dovid and prostrated herself to the ground.
24. She fell at his feet and said, “My master, with me lies the sin. Let your maidservant please speak in your ears, and hear the words of your maidservant.

25. Please let not my master set his heart against this wicked man, against Novol, for he is as his name implies, Novol is his name and villainy is his trait; and I, your maidservant, did not see my master’s youths whom you sent.

26. Now, my master, as Adonoy lives, and by your life, Adonoy has prevented you from shedding blood and from avenging yourself by your own hand; now may all your enemies be like Novol and those who seek evil against my master.
27. Now, this offering that your maidservant has brought to my master, let it be given to the youths who accompany my master.

28. Please pardon the sin of your maidservant, for Adonoy will surely make for my master an everlasting house, because the wars of Adonoy, my master fights, and no evil has been found in you all your days.

29. A man rose to pursue you and to seek your life; may my master’s soul be bound up in the bond of life, with Adonoy, your God, and may He cast away the soul of your enemies as one shoots [a stone] from a slingshot.
30. And may it be that when Adonoy does for my master according to all the good of which He has spoken about you, and appoints you as leader over Yisroel.

31. That this not be for you an obstacle and a stumbling block of the heart for my master, to have shed innocent blood and that my master has avenged himself. And when Adonoy has done good for my master, may you remember your maidservant.”
32. Dovid said to Avigayil, “Blessed be Adonoy, God of Yisroel, who sent you this day to meet me.
33. And blessed is your counsel and blessed are you, who prevented me this day from shedding blood and from avenging myself by my own hand.

34. Indeed, as Adonoy, God of Yisroel, lives, He prevented me from doing evil to you, for had you not hurried and come to meet me, for not so much would have remained to Novol—by the morning light—as a dog.”
35. Dovid then took from her what she had brought him, and he said to her, “Go up to peace to your house. See, I have heeded your advice, and I have honored your wish.”

36. Avigayil then came to Novol and behold, he was hosting a feast in his house, a feast fit for the king. Novol’s heart was in good spirits, and he was very drunk, so she did not tell him anything small or great until the morning’s light.
37. And it was in the morning, when Novol had sobered up, his wife told him about the whole incident, and his heart sank within him, and he became like a stone.
38. Then, after ten days, Adonoy struck Novol down and he died.

39. When Dovid heard that Novol had died, he said, “Blessed is Adonoy, Who has fought the battle of my disgrace from the hand of Novol, and has spared His servant from evil, and Novol’s evil Adonoy has returned upon his own head.” Dovid sent, inquiring of Avigayil, to take her as his wife.
40. Dovid’s servants came to Avigayil to Carmel and spoke to her, saying, “Dovid has sent us to you, to take you for himself as a wife.”
41. She rose and prostrated herself upon her face to the ground and said, “Behold, let your maidservant be a handmaid to wash the feet of my master’s servants.”
42. Avigayil then hurried and rose, and rode on the donkey, with her five youths going behind her. She followed Dovid’s messengers and became his wife.
43. Dovid also married Achino’am of Yizre’el, and both of them became his wives.
44. Shaul had given his daughter Michal, Dovid’s wife, to Palti the son of Layish of Gallim.
1. The Ziphites came to Shaul to Givah, saying, “Is not Dovid hiding himself in Givas Chachiloh, which faces Yeshimon?”
2. Shaul rose and went down to the wilderness of Ziph, with him were three thousand chosen men of Yisroel, to search for Dovid in the wilderness of Ziph.
3. Shaul camped at Givas Chachiloh, which faces Yeshimon, by the road. Dovid was staying in the wilderness, and he saw that Shaul had come after him, to the wilderness.
4. Dovid sent out scouts and he knew that Shaul had definitely come.

5. Dovid rose and came to the place where Shaul was camped. Dovid saw the place where they lay—Shaul and Avneir the son of Neir, the commander of his army; Shaul lay within the circle, and the people were camped around him.
6. Dovid spoke and said to Achimelech the Chiti and Avishai son of Tzeruyoh, Yo’av’s brother, saying, “Who will go down with me to Shaul, to the camp?” And Avishai said, “I will go down with you.”
7. So Dovid and Avishai came to the people at night, and behold, Shaul lay sleeping in the circle, his spear stuck into the ground at his head, and Avneir and the people lay around him.
8. Avishai said to Dovid, “God has delivered your enemy into your hand this day. Now, let me strike him with the spear to the ground with a single thrust, I will not need a second time.”
9. But Dovid said to Avishai, “Do not kill him, for who can send forth his hand against the anointed one of Adonoy and be free of guilt?”
10. Dovid said, “As Adonoy lives, Adonoy will strike him, or his day will come and he will die, or he will go down into battle and perish.
11. Adonoy forbid me from sending forth my hand against Adonoy’s anointed. Now, please take the spear that is near his head and the flask of water, and let us go.”

12. Dovid took the spear and the flask of water from next to Shaul’s head and they left without anyone seeing and without anyone knowing and without anyone waking up; for they were all asleep, because a deep sleep from Adonoy had fallen upon them.
13. Dovid then crossed to the other side and stood on the top of the mountain at a distance. There was considerable distance between them.
14. Dovid called out to the people and to Avneir son of Neir, saying, “Will you not answer, Avneir?” Avneir answered and said, “Who are you to call out to the king?”

15. Dovid said to Avneir, “Are you not a [great] man? Who is your equal in Yisroel? Why then have you not guarded your master, the king? For someone from among the people came to assassinate the king, your master.

16. This deed which is not proper—that you have done. As Adonoy lives, you are deserving of death for not having watched over your master, over the anointed one of Adonoy. Now, look where the king’s spear is and the flask of water that was near his head?”
17. Shaul recognized Dovid’s voice and said, “Is that your voice, my son Dovid?” Dovid replied, “It is my voice, my master, the king.”
18. And he said, “Why is it that my master pursues his servant? For what have I done? What evil is in my hand?

19. And now, let my master the king, hear the words of his servant. If it is Adonoy Who has incited you against me, let my offering be pleasing to him; but if it be men, let them be cursed before Adonoy, for they have driven me away this day from being joined to the inheritance of Adonoy, saying, ‘Go serve other gods.’
20. Now, let my blood not fall to the earth, away from the presence of Adonoy’s attention, for the king of Yisroel has come out to seek a single flea, as one hunting a partridge in the mountains.”
21. Shaul said, “I have sinned. Come back, my son Dovid, for I will no longer harm you, because my life was precious in your eyes this day. Behold, I have been foolish and have very greatly erred.”
22. Dovid then spoke up and said, “Here is the spear of the king, let one of the youths cross over and take it.

23. May Adonoy reward each man his righteousness and his faithfulness; for Adonoy has delivered you today into [my] hand, but I did not desire to send forth my hand against the anointed one of Adonoy.
24. Behold, just as your life was precious to me today in my eyes, so may my life be precious in the eyes of Adonoy, and may He save me from all misfortune.”
25. Shaul said to Dovid, “Blessed are you, my son Dovid. May you accomplish much and may you surely prevail.” Then Dovid went on his way and Shaul returned to his place.

1. Dovid said to himself, “Now I might perish one day at the hand of Shaul. There is nothing better for me [to do] than to escape to the land of the Philistines; for then Shaul will give up pursuing me anymore throughout Yisroel’s borders, and I will have escaped from his hand.”
2. Dovid rose and crossed over, with the six hundred men who were with him, to Achish son of Ma’och, king of Gas.
3. Dovid stayed with Achish in Gas, he and his men, each man with his household, Dovid with his two wives, Achinoam, the Yizre’elite and Avigayil, the Carmelite, the [former] wife of Novol.
4. It was told to Shaul that Dovid had fled to Gas, and he did not continue to search for him.

5. Dovid said to Achish, “If I have found favor in your eyes, let them give me a place in one of the countryside towns that I may settle there. Why should your servant remain in the royal city with you?”
6. So Achish gave him Tziklag on that day; therefore Tziklag belongs to the kings of Yehudah to this day.
7. The time that Dovid stayed in the Philistine countryside was days and four months.
8. Dovid and his men went up and raided the Geshurites, the Gizrites and the Amaleikites, for they had always dwelt in the land, in the direction of Shur to the land of Egypt.
9. Dovid would smite the [inhabitants of the] land, and he left no man or woman alive. He took sheep, cattle, donkeys, camels and clothing, and would return and come to Achish.
10. Achish would ask, “Where did you raid today?” And Dovid would say, “Against the south of Yehudah,” or “against the south of the Yerachme’elites,” or “to the south of the Kenites.”

11. Dovid left neither man nor woman alive to bring back [as a captive] to Gas, saying [to himself], “They might inform on us, saying, ‘This is what Dovid has done and this was his custom as long as he stayed in the Philistine countryside.’”
12. So Achish believed Dovid, saying [to himself], “He thoroughly detests his people Yisroel, and he will remain my servant always.”
1. At that time the Philistines gathered their camps into an army, to wage war against Yisroel. Achish said to Dovid, “You surely know that you will go out with me in the camp—you and your men.”
2. Dovid replied to Achish, “Therefore you will know what your servant will do.” Achish then said to Dovid, “Therefore as my bodyguard—I shall appoint you, permanently.”
3. Shmuel had died and all Yisroel mourned him and buried him in Romoh, in his city. Shaul had banished the Ovos and the Yidonim diviners from the land.
4. The Philistines gathered and they came and camped in Shunem; Shaul gathered all of Yisroel and they camped in Gilbo’a.
5. When Shaul saw the Philistine camp he became fearful and his heart trembled greatly.
6. Shaul inquired of Adonoy, but Adonoy did not answer him; neither through dreams, nor through the Urim, nor through the prophets.
7. Shaul said to his servants, “Seek out a medium of an Ov, and I will go to her and inquire of her.” His servants said to him, “Behold, there is a woman who is an Ov medium in Ein Dor.”

8. Shaul disguised himself and changed his clothing; he went together with two men. They came to the woman at night, and he said to her, “Please conjure an Ov for me, and bring up for me whomever I tell you.”
9. The woman said to him, “Behold, you know what Shaul did, that he has eliminated the Ovos and Yidonim from the land. Why then do you seek to entrap me, to have me killed?”
10. Shaul then swore to her by Adonoy, saying, “As Adonoy lives, no punishment shall befall you because of this thing.”
11. The woman asked, “Whom shall I conjure up for you?” And he said, “Bring Shmuel up for me.”
12. When the woman saw Shmuel, she screamed loudly. The woman said to Shaul saying, “Why did you deceive me? For you are Shaul!”
13. The king said to her, “Fear not. What did you see?” The woman said to Shaul, “I saw a godly man rising from the earth.”

14. He said to her, “What does he look like?” She said, “An old man is rising, and he is garbed in a robe.” Shaul knew that it was Shmuel, and he bowed with his face towards the ground and prostrated himself.

15. Shmuel said to Shaul, “Why have you disturbed me, to bring me up?” Shaul said, “I am in great distress, and the Philistines are at war against me; God has turned away from me and no longer answers me, neither through the prophets nor through dreams. Therefore I called upon you to tell me what to do.”
16. Shmuel said, “But why do you ask me when Adonoy has turned away from you and become your adversary?
17. Adonoy has done to him that which He said through me. Adonoy has torn the kingship from your hand and given it to your fellow, to Dovid.
18. Because you did not obey the word of Adonoy and did not execute His wrath against Amaleik, therefore Adonoy has done this thing to you today.

19. Adonoy will deliver Yisroel with you into the hand of the Philistines; tomorrow you and your sons will be with me, and also, the camp of Yisroel, will Adonoy deliver, into the hand of the Philistines.”
20. Shaul hastened and fell full length to the ground and he greatly feared Shmuel’s words; also, he had no strength in him because he had not eaten any food all day and all night.

21. The woman came to Shaul and saw that he was very terrified, and she said to him, “Behold, your maidservant heeded your voice and I put my life in my hand, and I listened to your words that you spoke to me.
22. So now you, too, please listen to the voice of your maidservant. I will put before you a loaf of bread. Eat, so that you will have strength when you go on the way.”
23. But he refused, and said, “I shall not eat.” His servants begged him, and so did the woman, and he listened to them. He got up from the ground and sat on the bed.
24. The woman had a fattened calf in her possession; she quickly slaughtered it, and took flour which she kneaded and baked into matzos.
25. She served it to Shaul and to his servants and they ate; and they got up and left that night.
1. The Philistines gathered together all their camps at Aiphek; Yisroel was camped at the spring that is in Yizre’el.
2. The Philistine governors crossed over with hundreds and thousands, and Dovid and his men crossed over last, with Achish.

3. The Philistine officers said, “Who are these Hebrews?” And Achish replied to the Philistine officers, “Why, this is Dovid, the servant of Shaul, king of Yisroel, who has been with me for these days or these years, and I have found no fault with him, from the day he settled [with me] to this day.”

4. But the Philistine officers were angry with him, and the Philistine officers said to him, “Send back the man, and let him return to his place that you assigned to him. Let him not go down with us to battle, so that he not be an adversary to us in the battle. How can this [person] prove his loyalty to his master? Is it not with the heads of those [Philistine] men?
5. Is this not Dovid, of whom they sing, accompanied with musical instruments, saying, ‘Shaul has slain his thousands, and Dovid his tens of thousands’?”

6. So Achish called Dovid and said to him, “As Adonoy lives, you are upright, and it is fine with me—your going out and coming back with me in the camp, for I have found no evil in you from the day you came to me until this day; but in the eyes of the governors you are not good.
7. Return, therefore, and go in peace, and do nothing that is evil in the eyes of the Philistine governors.”

8. Dovid then said to Achish, “But what have I done? What have you found in your servant from the day I have been before you to this day, that I should not come and fight against the enemies of my master the king?”
9. Achish answered, and said to Dovid, “I know, you are good in my eyes as an angel of God; but the Philistine officers have said, ‘He shall not go up with us into battle.’
10. So now, rise early in the morning together with the servants of your master who have come with you; rise early in the morning, and when you have light, go.”
11. Dovid and his men rose early, to leave in the morning, to return to the land of the Philistines, while the Philistines went up towards Yizre’el.
1. And it was when Dovid and his men came to Tziklag on the third day, the Amalekites had raided the south and Tziklag. They had attacked Tziklag and they set it on fire.
2. They had taken captive—the women in it—young and old, without killing anyone; they carried them off and went on their way.
3. When Dovid and his men came to the city, behold, it had been set on fire; and their wives, sons and daughters had been taken captive.
4. Dovid and the people who were with him raised their voices and wept, until they had no strength to weep.
5. Both of Dovid’s wives had been taken captive; Achinoam the Yezre’elite and Avigayil, the Carmelite, the [former] wife of Novol.

6. Dovid was very distressed, because the people spoke of stoning him, for the soul of all the people was embittered, each man over [the loss of] his sons and his daughters; but Dovid found strength in Adonoy his God.
7. Dovid said to Evyosor the kohein, the son of Achimelech, “Please, bring me the eiphod,” so Evyosor brought the eiphod to Dovid.

8. Dovid inquired of Adonoy, saying, “Shall I pursue this raiding party? Will I overtake it?” And He said to him, “Pursue, for you will surely overtake them and you will certainly rescue [the captives].”
9. Dovid went, he and the six hundred men who were with him, and they came to the Nachal Besor, where some of them remained behind.
10. Dovid pursued—he together with four hundred men—while two hundred men remained, who were too exhausted to cross the Nachal Besor.
11. They found an Egyptian man in the field and took him to Dovid. They gave him bread and he ate, and they gave him water to drink.
12. They gave him a cake of pressed figs and two clusters of raisins. He ate, and he came to himself, for he had neither eaten bread nor drunk water for three days and three nights.

13. Dovid said to him, “To whom do you belong and from where are you?” He said, “I am an Egyptian youth, the slave of an Amaleikite man. My master abandoned me because I have been ill for three days now.
14. We raided the south of the Kerethite and the territory of Yehudoh, and the south of Caleiv, and Tziklag we set on fire.”

15. Dovid said to him, “Will you take me down to this raiding party?” He replied, “Swear to me by God that you will neither kill me nor hand me over to my master, and I will take you down to this raiding party.”

16. He took him down and behold, they had spread across the entire land, eating, drinking and celebrating with all the great spoils which they had taken from the land of the Philistines and the land of Yehudoh.
17. Dovid attacked them from dusk until the evening of the next day; not one of them escaped, except four hundred youths who rode camels and fled.
18. Dovid recovered everything that Amaleik had taken, and Dovid rescued his two wives.
19. Nothing of theirs was missing, from small to great, sons and daughters, not the spoils, or anything they had taken for themselves; Dovid returned everything.
20. Then Dovid took all the sheep and cattle; they led them in front of the livestock and said, “This is Dovid’s booty.”

21. Dovid came to the two hundred men who were too exhausted to go follow after Dovid, whom he had left at the Nachal Besor. They went out to meet Dovid and to meet the people who were with him. Dovid approached the people and inquired after their welfare.

22. They spoke up—every evil and wicked person of the men who had gone with Dovid and said, “Because they did not go with me, we will not give them of the spoils that we recovered, except for each man’s wife and his children; let them lead them away and go.”
23. Dovid said, “My brothers, do not do so, with that which Adonoy has given us; He protected us and delivered the raiding party who came against us into our hand.
24. Who will listen to you concerning this matter? For as the share of the one that goes down into battle, so is the share of the one who stays with the equipment; they shall share equally.”
25. From that day on, he made this a statute and a law for Yisroel, until this day.
26. When Dovid came to Tziklag, he sent of the spoils to the elders of Yehudoh, to his allies, saying, “Here is a present for you, from the spoils of the enemies of Adonoy.”
27. [He sent booty] to those in Beis Eil, to those in Ramos Negev, to those in Yattir.
28. To those in Aroe’er, to those in Siphmos, to those in Eshtemo’a.
29. To those in Rochol, to those in the Yerachme’elite cities, to those in the Kenite cities.
30. To those in Chormoh, to those in Bechor Oshon, and to those in Asoch.
31. To those in Chevron, and to all those places where Dovid had gone—he and his men.
1. The Philistines were battling with Yisroel, and the men of Yisroel fled from the Philistines and fell slain on Har Gilbo’a.
2. The Philistines overtook Shaul and his sons, and the Philistines slew Yonoson, Avinodov, and Malki Shua, the sons of Shaul.
3. The battle then turned against Shaul; the archers who shot at him with bows found him, and he was very terrified of the archers.

4. Shaul said to his armsbearer, “Draw your sword and stab me, lest these uncircumcised men come and stab me and make sport of me.” But his armsbearer did not want to do so, for he was very frightened; so Shaul took the sword and fell upon it.
5. When his armsbearer saw that Shaul was dead, he also fell upon his sword and died with him.
6. Shaul died, and his three sons, and his armsbearer, as well as all his men, together on that day.

7. When the men of Yisroel saw—those who were on the other side of the valley and on the other side of the Yardein—that the men of Yisroel fled and that Shaul and his sons were dead, they abandoned their cities and fled. The Philistines then came and settled in them.
8. On the next day, when the Philistines came to strip the corpses, they found Shaul and his three sons, fallen on Har Gilbo’a.
9. They cut off his head and stripped off his armor, and sent [them] in the land of the Philistines—throughout—to bring the news to the temples of their idols and to the people.
10. They placed his armor in the temple of Ashtoros, and they hung his body on the wall of Beis Shon.
11. They heard about him—the inhabitants of Yoveish Gilod—about what the Philistines had done to Shaul.
12. All the men of valor rose and went that entire night, and they removed Shaul’s body and his sons’ bodies from the wall of Beis Shon; they came to Yoveish and burned them there.
13. They took their bones and buried them under the tamarisk tree in Yoveish, and they fasted seven days.

appendix.p: [[1]] And there was a man. It all follows the order: Moshe gave over the Torah to Yehoshua and Yehoshua to the Elders and each Judge to his successor until it reached Eili who gave it over to Shmuel1 as we learned (in the Mishnah), “… and the Elders [gave it over] to the Prophets…”2
From Ramasayim Tsofim. There were two hills each visible to the other.3 4 Targum Yonoson renders צוֹפִים: “of the disciples of prophets.”
Elkonoh. He was a Levite of the sons of Aviosof, the son of Korach —his ancestry is thus recorded in Divrei Hayomim.5

From the land of Ephrayim. [Targum] Yonoson renders “on the mountain of the house of Ephrayim.” The Midrash Aggadah [renders] אֶפְרָתִי —a palace dweller, an important person,6 as in “let us extend אַפִּרְיוֹן to Rabbi Shimon,”7 [meaning] an expression of favor.

[[3]] This man would go up. This is the present tense, i.e., he would go up from one appointed season to another, to Shilo.8 The Midrash Aggadah [renders] that the route he followed this year he did not take the next year in order to publicize [his pilgrimage] to the Bnei Yisroel that they should do likewise.9
[[4]] It happened on the day. It happened on the festive day.
[[5]] One choice portion. One choice portion which is fit to be accepted with a friendly countenance.10
[[6]] Her rival. Her husband’s other wife, Penina.
Frequently anger. Anger after anger, i.e., always.’ Therefore it is written ‘also [גֵם] anger.’ She would say to her, “Did you buy your older son a cloak today, or your younger son, a shirt?”
In order that she should complain. In order to make her complain. Our Rabbis explain, ‘in order to make her storm,’ that she pray. Penina had good intentions.11
Her womb. Lit., opposite her womb, and so is every expression of the word .12בְּעַד
[[7]] He would do this. Elkonoh.

Year after year. He would give her a choice portion to demonstrate to her that he loved her; and her rival, according to the affection which her husband demonstrated to her, would anger her more and more.
[[8]] Am I not better to you. Don’t I love you more dearly.
Than ten sons. That Penina has borne to me.13

[[9]] Eating in Shilo. The ‘ה’ is not dotted and the ‘א’ is voweled with a short kametz and its [meaning is] ‘after eating in Shilo and after drinking,’14 and this expression is properly used both for masculine and feminine. After אָכְלָה is a gerund. It is constructed like ,15לְאָכְלָה an expression equivalent to an infinitive [i.e., לֶאֶכוֹל].
And Eili the kohen was sitting on the chair. On that day he was seated on a large chair,16 for he was appointed Judge over Yisroel.
Near the doorpost. [Lit. on the doorpost] meaning near the doorpost.

[[11]] Adonoy of Hosts. Why was this Name designated here? She [Chana] said before Him, “Lord of the universe, You created two hosts in Your world. The heavenly beings neither multiply nor do they die; the earthly beings both multiply and die. If I am of the earthly beings, let me multiply and die, and if I am of the heavenly beings, let me not die.” I found [this explanation] in the Aggadah of R. Eliezer the son of R. Yose Haglili. Our Rabbis in Maseches Berachos,17 expounded what they expounded: —Until then, there was no one person who called the Holy One, Blessed is He, [Master of] Hosts. She said thus before Him; “Lord of the universe, of all the hosts which You created in Your world, is it difficult for you to grant me one son?”
If You look at. In Maseches Berachos,18 our Sages expounded what they expounded.
Your maidservant. [The word ‘maidservant’] is stated three times in this verse, corresponding to the three mitzvos which a woman is commanded to observe.19
Male offspring. I.e., righteous men, as it is written, “Two men [אֲנָשִׁים] who were righteous.”20
Males. I.e., important men,21 as it is written, “wise… and known men ]אֲנָשִׁים[.22
Then I will give him to Adonoy. I.e., that he be fit to be given to Adonoy.
And a razor.23 Targum Yonoson renders, “and the fear [וּמַרְוַת] of man will not be upon him.”
[[12]] Watched her mouth. He waited for her to stop, as Targum Yonoson renders, ‘and Eili waited until she stopped.’
Watched. An expression of waiting, as in, “[and his father] kept the matter in mind ]שָׁמַר[”24 i.e., waited, [and similarly] “do not wait [תִשְׁמוֹר] for my sin.”25
[[13]] Eili thought she was drunk. Because they were not accustomed to praying silently.
[[15]] No, my lord. You are not master in this matter. You have revealed that the Holy Spirit is not resting upon you, otherwise you would have known that I am not intoxicated from wine.26
[[16]] Do not deliver your maidservant. Because she had spoken harshly to him, she tried to appease him, so that he deliver her not, unprotected and disgraced, to her rival, the wicked woman.
For it is out of much grievance. That I have spoken harshly to you.

Grievance. In some instances, it [שִֹיחִי] is an expression of heartache. Another explanation of מֵרֹב שִֹיחִי, according to Targum, “because of much provocation and anger, I have prolonged my prayer until now.”
And anger. My rival angers me.
Do not deliver. An expression of giving over, as in, “‘Do not deliver me to the will of my tormentors.”27
[[17]] Your request. The א is missing, to infer [שֵׁלָתֵךְ] an expression of children,28 as in, “and her young [וּבְשִׁלְיָתָהּ] who emerges from….”29
Will grant the request. He foretold to her that her prayer had been accepted.
[[18]] May your maidservant find favor. To beg for compassion on her behalf.
And no longer had the [sad] look on her face. Meaning the face of anger.
[[19]] And came to their home… and Elkonoh knew. From here [we learn] that a traveler is forbidden to have marital relations.30

[[20]] And as the seasons and days passed. The minimum of seasons [תְּקוּפוֹת] is two, and the minimum of days [יָמִים] is two. Hence, [she gave birth] after six months [=two seasons] and two days.31 From here [we learn] that a woman who gives birth in her seventh month of pregnancy, can give birth after entering part of the seventh month.
Shmuel. After the Name of God [א־ל], and in reference to the incident he was so called, for I requested [שָׁאַל] him of הַשֵׁם [=מא־ל].
[[21]] The festival offering. [Targum renders] the sacrifices of the appointed seasons.
And his vow. The vows he made between festivals he would offer on the next festival.32
[[22]] When [the boy] will be weaned. At the end of twenty-two (other versions, twenty-four) months, for that is the period for a child to nurse.

And shall remain there forever. Forever in the Levitic sense,33 i.e., fifty years as it is said, “from the age of fifty he shall retire from the work force.”34 Figuring as follows, we determine that Shmuel’s lifetime was fifty-two years: Eili judged Yisroel for forty years.35 On the day of Chana’s prayer he was appointed judge.36 By subtracting the year in which Chana conceived Shmuel, there remain thirty-nine years. Shmuel governed Yisroel from the time of Eili’s death for thirteen years, as follows: On the day of Eili’s death, the Ark was captured, and it remained in the land of the Philistines for seven months.37 From there, it was brought to and remained in Kiryas Yearim until Dovid brought it up after he had reigned seven years in Chevron over Yehudah, and all of Yisroel had accepted him as their king. And it is written, “From the day the Ark came to rest in Kiryas Yearim, there ensued many days, and they became twenty years.”38 Subtracting from them seven years which Dovid reigned in Chevron discloses that from the time the Ark was captured until Shaul’s death, were thirteen years and seven months; and Shmuel died four months before Shaul.

[[23]] But may Adonoy fulfill His word. Because you requested of Him male offspring,39 and Eili foretold you through Divine inspiration, “the God of Yisroel will grant your request,”40 may ‘ה fulfill His word. This is the simple interpretation. In Midrash Aggadah, however, Rabbi Nechemyah said in the name of Rabbi Shmuel, the son of Rabbi Yitzchok: Every day a Divine voice would resound throughout the world and say, “A righteous man is destined to arise, by the name of Shmuel.” Thereupon, every woman who bore a son, would name him Shmuel. Once they saw his deeds, they would say, “This is not [the] Shmuel.” But when this one [Shmuel] was born and people saw his deeds, they said, “Apparently this one is the one [i.e., expected righteous man].” This is what he [Elkonoh] meant when he said, “May Adonoy fulfill His word,” i.e., that this be the righteous Shmuel.

[[24]] One eiphah of flour. I heard in the name of Rabbi Yitzchok Halevi, that she brought one eiphah of flour, the equivalent of three seahs, from which to extract three tenths of an eiphah of fine flour, the required amount for one bull.41 As we learned in the Mishnah:42 The showbread was made of twenty-four tenths of an eiphah from twenty-four seahs; i.e., one tenth part of an eiphah of fine flour from each seah of wheat.
And a flask of wine. For a libation.
Though the child was still a lad. The Targum renders, ‘though the child was still young.’

[[25]] They brought the child to Eili. To show that his prophecy was fulfilled. Our Sages expounded what they expounded, explaining that he [Shmuel] ruled on a point of law, that a kohein is not necessary for sacrificial slaughter, as it is stated in [Maseches] Berachos.43
[[26]] Please my lord. Take care of him, that he become your disciple. But according to the Midrash of our Sages, [she asked of Eili] not to punish him with death.
[[27]] This is the child that I prayed for. Do not say, “this one shall die and another shall be given to you.”44
[[28]] And I have dedicated him to Adonoy. Just as a person who lends a utensil to his master, or lends him his son to serve him.

He is dedicated. Enpruntez in Old French, i.e., you have no right to punish him, for the Holy one, Blessed is He, has become his borrower; because I have lent [Shmuel] to Him, He must return him to me.45
He then prostrated himself. Shmuel. Others say, Elkonoh.
appendix.ftnote: 1I.e., the “ו” of וְאֵלֶה links the Book of Shmuel with the preceeding Book of Shoftim and serves as a link between the oral tradition as stated in the Mishnah, “…and the Elders…”
3Elkonoh lived in Romoh, see below verse 19; and he prophesied in Tsofim—Da’as Sofrim.
6Rashi emphasizes that אֶפְרָתִי does not mean that he was from the tribe of Ephrayim because it has already been established that he was from the tribe of Leivi.
8He would go to Shiloh on the three pilgrimage festivals of Pesach, Shavuos and Sukkos.
10אַפָּיִם referring to the face rather than to the portion. Ralbag renders “a double sized portion.”

13Others interpret that Elkonoh did not mean literally ten sons and with reference to Penina, but rather he was expressing his love to Chana and happened to pick that number [[10]], as we find the same number in Vayikra 26:26.—Radak
14Eili therefore suspected that she was drunk because prayer usually takes place before eating or drinking—Da’as Sofrim.
16The defective spelling of ישֵׁב [instead of יוֹשֵׁב] indicates that he just recently sat down because he was a newly appointed judge. See Rashi Bereishis 19:1.
19They are the laws of: 1. Menstruation .2 נִדָּה Separation of the dough .3 חַלָּה Kindling of the Shabbos lights [הַדְלָקַת הַנֵּר].

23See Maseches Nazir 66a where the very same difference of opinion is discussed. R. Nehorai renders מוֹרָה meaning a razor as Scripture states regarding Shimshon, in Shoftim 13:5, “the razor [מוֹרָה] must not be wielded on his head.” And R. Yose holds that [מוֹרָה] is a connotation referring to the fear of man.

28Others render שֵׁלָתֵך as being derived from שָׁלָל [=plunder], meaning that her soon to be born son will “take of the goods [שָׁלָל of the Torah,” i.e., he will gain much knowledge and understanding of the Torah.—Radak
33It can also refer to the fifty year period of Yoveil.

45Another interpretation of “שָׁאוּל” is that it refers to Shaul. She stated by Divine inspiration, “as long as Shmuel lives, Shaul will live.” Shmuel was no longer alive at the time of Shaul’s death.

appendix.p: [[1]] My mouth is enlarged. Against Penina.
[[2]] And there is no stronghold like our God. There is no artist1 [צַיָר] like our God Who fashions a form within a form.2

[[3]] Do not abound in speaking so very proudly. All those who are haughty when they experience good fortune. About Penina who behaved haughtily toward her, was she speaking, according to the simple explanation. However, according to the drash, we follow Targum Yonoson’s rendition [that she is referring to Nevuchadnetzar].

Harshness. Strong speech. Others explain עָתָק as an expression of something which is removed [from the truth], as in “from there he moved [וַיַעְתֵּק] to the mountain.”3 [The meaning here being “let not] falsehood come out of your mouth.”
For a God of knowledge is Adonoy. He knows what is in your hearts.
And by Him all actions are counted. All people’s deeds are counted before Him.
Counted. An expression of number, as in, “and the number [וְתֹכֶן] of bricks shall you give.”4
[[4]] The bows of the mighty are broken… This is the custom of the Holy One, Blessed is He. He weakens the mighty and strengthens the weak, He sates the hungry and starves the sated.
[[5]] The sated have hired themselves out for bread. [The sated] who do not need to hire themselves out for any work, He starves them and they must hire themselves out for bread,
And the hungry Who would toil and weary themselves for food.
Have ceased. From their toil.

Until the barren has born seven and she with many children…. While the barren woman has born seven,5 she that had many children has been bereaved and buries her children. Chana bore seven as it is stated, “For Adonoy remembered Chana and she conceived and gave birth to three sons and two daughters.” When Chana bore one, Penina buried two.6 Penina had ten children as it is stated, “Am I not better to you than [the] ten sons of Penina?”7 When Chana bore four, Penina buried eight. When she [Chana] conceived and bore a fifth child, Penina prostrated herself at her feet and begged for mercy and they lived and were therefore considered as hers. This is R. Nechemya’s opinion. R. Yehudah however says that grandchildren are considered as children. Some are of the opinion that the numerical value of שִׁבְעָה (377) is equivalent to that of שְׁמוּאֵל (377).

[[9]] His pious ones. It is spelled חֲסִידוֹ “His pious one” but read חֲסִידָיו “His pious ones,” [meaning] whether a single one or many. Similarly “may His adversaries be broken.” [The reading is מְרִיבָיו “His adversaries” but] the spelling is מְרִיבוֹ “His adversary,” meaning whether a single adversary or many.
[[10]] Let Him thunder against them from heaven. The spelling is עָלוּ “they have ascended” meaning that even if they have ascended to the heavens, He thunders upon them and casts them down.
May Adonoy judge the ends of the earth. He judges and punishes them. Justisier in O. F.
[[11]] Served Adonoy in the presence of Eili the kohein. From here [our Sages conclude] that “whoever serves before a Torah scholar is considered as though he had served before the Divine Presence.”8
[[13]] The custom of the kohanim. They established this law for themselves, since they rightfully inherited only the breast and the thigh of the peace offering.
[[14]] Pot. Fire pot.
Pan. Cauldron.
Bowl. Pan.
[[17]] They had disgraced. Meaning despised.

[[18]] A lad girded with a linen robe. [Targum renders] “כַּרְדּוּט of linen,” meaning a robe, for Targum Yonoson renders מְעִילִים in the passage כִּי כֵן תִּלְבַּשְׁנָה הַבְּתוּלוֹת מְעִילִים “for such so מְעִילִים were worn by the maidens…”,9 as כַּרְדוּטִין.
[[19]] His mother would make for him a small robe. From year to year.
[[20]] Eili would then bless them. This is the present tense, i.e., he would bless him every year.

Because of the request that he had made. For himself a son. [Eili] would say to him, “May השם grant you seed, etc., i.e., may it be the Divine Will that all the children that you will have, will be from this righteous woman. This is an inverted sentence.

[[22]] That they would lie. The explanation is according to the simple sense. Our Rabbis however said10 that since they delayed [the sacrifice of] their birds11 and they would wait until they would see their birds being offered, Scripture charges them as though they had lain with them.12

[[24]] That I hear being passed on by Adonoy’s people. The rumor which השם’s people are spreading about you, an expression similar to, “and they proclaimed [וַיַעֲבִירוּ] throughout the camp;13 meaning, they let out a rumor about you which is not good.14
[[25]] Tries him. וּפִלְלוֹ is an expression of judgment, as in, “and he shall pay by order of the judges ]פְלִילִים[.”15
Judge. The judge.
For it was Adonoy’s will to kill them. For their verdict had already been sealed.16 Before the verdict is sealed however, Scripture states, “for I do not desire the death of one who should die.”17
[[27]] The man of God came. This was Elkonoh.

Have I not repeatedly revealed Myself to your ancestor’s family. From here [our Sages concluded] that Aharon prophesied in Egypt. What was the prophecy? It is stated, “and I said to them, ‘Every man, cast away the detestable idols of his eyes, do not defile yourselves with the idols of Egypt.’”18
Have I not repeatėdly revealed Myself. Did you know that this favor and greatness I gave to Aharon.19
[[29]] Which I commanded you [to bring in My] Sanctuary. Which I commanded in My dwelling place.

To feed yourselves from the choice parts… This is an inverted sentence [meaning], “you honor your sons more than Me ,” ]לְעַמִּי[ before My people, i.e., in the eyes of My people, you honor your sons more than Me. And what is the honor? To feed yourselves from the choice parts of all the offerings of Yisroel. Your meal preceded My meal, as it is stated, “even before they would burn the fat…”20
To feed yourselves. [לְהַבְרִיאֲכֶם] is an expression of having a meal, as in, “Please let my sister Tamar come and serve [וְתַבְרֵנִי] me bread.”21

My people. This reverts to, “you honor your sons more than Me.” You showed My people that you are more honored than I. And how have you shown this? By feeding yourselves from the choice parts of My offerings.22

[[30]] I had indeed decreed. Twice I assigned greatness to the sons of Isomor: Concerning the sons of Gershon and the sons of Merori, it is stated, “Under the direction of Isomor, the son of Aharon the kohein.”23 And Eili was one of the descendants of Isomor. This [explanation] I saw in Midrash Shmuel. I have, however, heard a more fitting explanation: “I had indeed decreed that your family and your father’s family…” Originally I made Elozor the kohein to serve as kohein gadol, as it is stated, “remove Aharon’s vestments, [and dress Elozor his son in them].”24 However, at the time of the concubine,25 Yisroel divested themselves of most mitzvos. And who was to blame [for this]? Pinchas and his associate kohanim, who should have gone around from city to city to reprove them. I therefore took the kehunah gedolah away from them, and gave it to you, for you are of Isomor’s descendants, and I said, that they shall walk before Me forever; for when greatness is assigned to a person, it is assigned to him and to his generations forever.

For I honor those who honor Me. Pinchas’ descendants who honored Me at Shittim.26 And this happened in the days of Shlomo, that when the Temple was built, Shlomo dismissed Evyosor from being a kohein [gadol] to ‘ה, fulfilling the word of ‘ה which He had spoken concerning Eili’s family.27 And Tzadok became the kohein gadol, because he was of Pinchas’ descendants; he is so listed in the genealogical records in Divrei Hayomim.28
And those who dishonor Me will be cursed. By. themselves, when I will withdraw Myself from them.29
[[31]] I shall cut off your arm. I.e., the power which you exert in My House, for you say, “or else I will take it by force.”
[[32]] And you will see a rival [in My] Sanctuary. And you will see your rival at your side in My Sanctuary just as a woman who sees her rival with her in the house.

Throughout all the good that He will bring upon Yisroel. When the Temple will be built in the days of Shlomo, and the goodness promised to Yisroel will be complete, as it is said there, “Not one word has gone unfulfilled from His entire gracious promise.30 Yehudah and Yisroel were numerous, like the sand that is by the sea.31 And Yehudah and Yisroel dwelt in security, each man under his grapevine and under his fig tree… all the days of Shlomo.”32
But there will be no elder in your family. This is an appropriate punishment. You ate sacrifices before the [permitted] time, before they burnt the fat, so too, you will die before your time.
[[33]] And sadden. וְלַאֲדִיב is the same as 33וְלַדְאִיב [disillusioned].
Will die as [young] men. Young. There is no comparison between the mourning for a young man and the mourning for a child.34

[[34]] This is the sign to you. That the prophecy will be fulfilled: In one day your two sons will die, and this will be the sign for you for the fulfillment35 of all the retribution that was said to you, “and you will see a rival in My Sanctuary,” “and all those raised in your house will die as [young] men.”36
[[35]] A faithful kohein. Tzadok.
[[36]] For a silver coin. In order to earn a מָעָה silver coin.
Silver coin. with a weight of twenty gerah.37
Let me be included. Let me to join.
appendix.ftnote: 1 Rashi disregards the usual rendering of צוֹר [=Rock], which represents the awesome powers of ‘ה Who is able to change the laws of nature. Seen Devarim 32:4.
5 Others interpret that the seven children mentioned are not literally seven and with reference to Peninah, but rather it is an expression that means “many children.” See above 1:8.—Radak
8Talmud Yerushalmi Eruvin 5:1. The reason being that a Torah scholar cleaves to ‘ה in his thoughts at all times so that even his physical activities are holy.

12See Maseches Shabbos 55b. Metzudas Dovid translates this phrase as “they would cause the women who assembled at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting to sleep there,” thereby not allowing them to return to their homes and husbands.
14Although it was only a rumor, kohanim are held accountable even for an appearance of impropriety.
19Ralbag interprets this phrase as an affirmative statement, i.e., “I did indeed reveal myself to the…”
22It may also be interpreted as referring to the part of the sacrifice that belonged to the people who brought the offering, that Eili’s sons took for themselves.
29Referring to Eili’s sons from whom the kehunah gedolah would be removed in the time of Shlomo Hamelech.
34Whose loss though tragic, is less keenly felt than the loss of a young man.
35He needed a sign in the near future to authenticate the prophecy that all the punishments described will come true.

appendix.p: [[1]] Was rare. Was withheld,1 as in, “and a man of understanding speaks sparingly ]יֲקר[”,2 meaning that who speaks sparingly is an understanding man.
Prophetic vision was not widespread. Prophecy was not revealed.3 נִפְרָץ is an expression similar to, “and you shall spread [וּפָרַצְתָּ] westward and eastward.4
[[3]] And Shmuel was lying. In his place, in the court of the Levites who watch in the Temple. According to Targum Yonoson: “And Shmuel was lying in the court of the Levites.”
In the Temple of Adonoy. Where the Ark of God was.

[[4]] Adonoy called. And a voice emanated from the Temple of God, from the Holy of Holies, which called, “Shmuel!” The end of the above verse5 is connected to the verse that follows. This is what is inferred by the verse, “the Lord thunders wonderously with His voice.”6 Eili was a kohein, and was watching from within, while Shmuel was a Levite and lying without. Yet, the voice [of ‘ה] jumped over Eili to Shmuel.

[[7]] [Shmuel] had not yet known Adonoy. He had not yet recognized the nature of the prophetic voice.7 Every time the word ‘טֶרֶם’ appears in Scripture, it means ‘not yet,’ as rendered by the Targum ‘עַד לָא’ [not yet]. It does not mean ‘before.’ This verse proves it. And another [proof of this] is the verse כִּי טֶרֶם תִּירְאוּן which is rendered as “that you do not yet fear,”8 is a more explicit verse proving this. Also, וְכֹל שִֹיחַ הַשָֹּדֶה טֶרֶם יִהְיֶה בָאָרֶץ [“all plants of the field were not yet on the earth”].9
[[10]] And Shmuel said, “Speak.” He did not mention the Name of the Deity as Eili had commanded him, because he said [to himself], ‘Perhaps it is another voice.’10
[[11]] To do something. This refers to the capture of the Ark by the Philistines.11
Will ring. An expression similar to [צִלְצָלִים], cymbals, tintiner, in O. F.

[[12]] I will begin to destroy. On that day, My decree upon Eili’s family will begin, for Chofni and Pinchas shall die, and from then on, I shall finish my decree and complete it upon them from generation to generation, and cause them to die as young men at the age of eighteen years.
I will begin to destroy. Commencant e espleiant, in O. F.
[[13]] That his sons were blaspheming themselves. It should properly state, ‘blaspheming Me’ but Scripture euphemized.12
Blaspheming. Meaning, acting irreverantly, and similarly, every curse [קְלָלָה] is an expression of irreverence and disgrace.
He did not censure. I.e., he did not darken [כהה] their faces by removing them from their high positions.
[[17]] Such shall [God] do to you. Like that very curse, that you shall not have worthy children. And that curse actually befell him even though he did tell him.
[[18]] And did not withhold. From here [the Sages concluded]: A curse of a wise man, even though pronounced on condition, will be realized.13
He is Adonoy. He is the Master and everything is His.

[[21]] For Adonoy revealed Himself to Shmuel. Because Scripture stated above, “The word of Adonoy was rare in those days,”14 it states here that from now on, for Shmuel’s sake, He revealed Himself repeatedly.15
appendix.ftnote: 1It was therefore considered precious and dear [=יָקָר].

3Not only were prophetic visions rare in those days, but even when they occurred they were not clear and concise, but rather cryptic and vague. Also, the prophecy that was received was of a private nature and not required by the people, so there was no need to reveal those visions. The prophets therefore kept their experiences to themselves and prophetic vision was rare and not widespread.
5As is indicated by the אֶתְנַחְתָּא under the word שֹׁכֵכ to separate it from ‘בְּהֵיכַל ה.
7He was thus unfamiliar with the ways ‘ה calls man, and he therefore thought that the voice was Eili’s.
11Also, this may be referring to the destruction of the Mishkon in Shiloh which happened after the Ark was captured.

12 See Mechilta Beshalach 15:7 for a listing of other places where Scripture euphemized out of reverence to ‘ה. Ralbag, however, interprets this verse that “they [Bnei Yisroel] cursed them [the sons of Eili].”
15Not only to Shmuel, but others also began to prophesy.

appendix.p: [[1]] The word of Shmuel went out to all of Yisroel. The word which was said to Shmuel, was fulfilled, and came to all Yisroel. How did this misfortune befall them? “Yisroel went out to war against the Philistines.”1
Even Haezer [Lit. the rock of help]. This was not yet its name,2 for it was first called this name [later] in Shmuel’s time, but here Scripture calls it by its future name.

[[2]] And the war spread. And the war spread. Similar to, “and behold they were spread out [נְטוּשִׁים] across the face of the entire land”3 and to “and they were spread out [וַיִנָּטְשׁוּ] at Lehi.”4

[[8]] With every sort of plague in the wilderness. By the Sea of Reeds. Targum Yonoson however, renders, ‘and for His people He performed wonders in the wilderness.’ In Sifrei we learn that this passage is a combination of statements, whoever made one statement did not make the other. The worthy among them said, “Who will save us from the hand of this mighty God?” while the wicked retorted, “This is the God Who smote the Egyptians with every plague. All the plagues which He had, He brought upon the Egyptians. He has no more plagues [to inflict].”
[[12]] A Binyaminite man. This was Shaul,5 who grabbed the Tablets from the hands of Golyas and fled.
[[13]] By the road looking out. By the side of the road, he was anxiously waiting.6
[[18]] His neck. [Targum renders] אַפַּרְקוּתֵיה, the bone of the neck.7

[[19]] To give birth. Obviously [this word] means ‘to give birth.’ There is no similar form [in Scriptures]. However, Menachem8 placed this verb in the section dealing with the word יְלָלָה ‘wailing,’ because her birth pangs came upon her with wailing. The root of ‘יְלָלָה’ is the ‘ל’ alone.
Came suddenly. Differed from what normally occurs, therefore she died.
Her labor pains. [צִרֶיהָ=hinges], i.e., ‘the hinges of the doors of her womb’;9 chardonel in O. F.
[[21]] I chavod. There is no glory; similar to, “He will save ”10אִי נָקִי one who is not innocent, [meaning the same as] אֵין נָקִי.
Because of the capture of. Meaning the same as ‘to the capture of’, but it is unnecessary to remove the expression of ‘to’ for one who understands its meaning.
Because of the capture of. Envers etweirs l’estre pris in O. F.
And because of her father-in-law. I.e., because of this misfortune that her father-in-law and husband had perished.
appendix.ftnote: 1When Bnei Yisroel deserved punishment, ‘ה sometimes commanded them to go out and battle the Philistines even though it would end in their defeat.—Radak
2 Obviously, because they were soundly defeated now.
5Perhaps the reason for Scripture not revealing that it was Shaul, was to protect the honor of his kingship being that he was responsible in part for Eili’s death.—Da’as Sofrim
6He wanted to be situated in a place where a messenger would have to pass him first, and thus give him the news.
7מַפְרֶקֶת is derived from פֶּרֶק [=link], meaning vertebra of which the bones of the neck and spine are made.
8Menachem was an authority on grammar and is often quoted by Rashi.

appendix.p: [[2]] Beside Dagon. The idol was made in the form of a fish.1
[[4]] The threshold. The equivalent of אַסְקוּפָה [=threshold].
[[6]] And He devastated them. An expression [שְׁמָמָה] meaning desolation.
With hemorrhoids. The mesentery of the large intestine, a plague of the rectum. Mice would enter their recta, disembowel them, and crawl out.

[[9]] And they were afflicted internally. וַיִשָֹּתְרוּ is identical with וַיִסָּתְרוּ for it is listed in the Masora among those words written with a ‘שֹ’ and explained as though it were written with a ‘ס’ meaning “there was a plague in the hidden parts of the body.”2

[[11]] Deadly upheaval. All upheavals [mentioned in Scripture] are caused by thunder. The following is the origin: “Adonoy thundered with a great noise on that day against the Philistines, making them panic.3 It is so explained in the Aggadah of Thirty-Two Rules of R. Eliezer, the son of R. Yose Haglili.
appendix.ftnote: 1 From the word דָג [=fish]. Some say that from the waist up it had a human form with hands, and from the waist down it looked like a fish.
2Or it may mean that the plague occurred at night when it was dark and they were unable to see the שְׁרָצִים, i.e., the plague was hidden from them.—Da’as Sofrim

appendix.p: [[2]] How we should send it back. In what manner should we send it away, so that He will not be angry, and so that His wrath will be removed from us.
[[3]] A guilt-offering. As an indication that you confess that you have betrayed Him.
Then you will be healed, and you will realize. That He did this, for why wouldn’t His hand turn away from you then?
[[4]] Philistine rulers. They were five, as it is stated, “The Azites, the Ashdodites, the Ashkelonites, the Gittites, and the Ekronites.”1
[[7]] Nursing cows. Nursing.

Which have not borne a yoke. All this is for the test. Since these cows are not capable of pulling [a load], and furthermore, they will yearn for their young. If the Ark will have the power to enable them to pull it by themselves, we shall know that He brought this upon us.
[[8]] In the box. Escrin in O. F.
[[10]] Confined in the house. ‘כָּלוּ’ is an expression of ‘כֶּלֶא’ [imprisonment].

[[12]] Set on a straight course. This word is a grammatical hermaphrodite.2 This teaches us that even the young recited a song,3 “Sing aloud, sing aloud, O Ark of acacia wood! Exalt yourself…” as stated in Maseches Avodah Zorah.4 According to its simple meaning, ‘וַיִשַּׁרְנָה’ is an expression meaning ‘straight,’ i.e. they followed a straight path.
Lowing as they walked. This is an expression of the cry [גְּעִיָה] of cattle.
Beis Shemesh. Yisroel was there.5
[[13]] And they rejoiced to see. They were going to see how it came alone, and out of their joy, they behaved with levity, for they did not gaze at it with awe and respect.6
[[18]] Open village. A village without a wall.

The large rock. This is the large rock previously mentioned, for the ‘ל’ comes in place of the ‘נ’ [in the word ‘אָבֵל’], similar to ‘נִשְׁכָּה’ instead of ‘לִשְׁכָּה’ [chamber], in the book of Nechemyah.7 And because they experienced mourning there,8 they called it ‘אָבֵל’.

[[19]] Seventy men, fifty thousand men.9 Targum Yonoson renders, ‘And He killed of the elders of the people seventy men, and of the community fifty thousand men.’9 Our Rabbis, however said, ‘Seventy men, each of whom was equal to fifty thousand, or fifty thousand men each of whom was equal to the seventy of Sanhedrin.’10
appendix.ftnote: 2The “י” of וַיִשַּׁרְנָה is the masculine form and the “נה” is indicative of the feminine form.
3 And, therefore, the combination of the masculine and feminine forms.
4 24b. The cows literally sang an intelligible praise to ‘ה. They were given the miraculous power to sing just as Bilam’s donkey was given the power of speech in Bamidbar 22:28-30.
